extractions.extraction_text: So the next one we want to talking about the data set. We have different type of data set. You might heard about the term called structured data or unstructured data.
Structured data is you know exactly the meaning about the row and column.

attributes.definition: Data where the meaning of rows and columns is precisely known.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that is organized in a predictable way, like in tables with rows and columns, where each piece of information has a clear meaning.

extractions.extraction_text: Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

attributes.definition: Data that is complex and varied, often derived from human-generated content like text, images, and videos, and can be difficult to interpret.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Data that doesn't have a predefined format, like emails, social media posts, or videos. It's harder to organize and analyze automatically.

extractions.extraction_text: Luckily with this AI thing and right now text, image, video already can be converting into structured format, but you still need to be able to know once we convert, are they meaningful or not.

attributes.summary_of_insight: AI can help convert unstructured data (text, images, video) into a structured format, but human oversight is still needed to ensure the converted data is meaningful.

extractions.extraction_text: So we have different kind of characteristic about our data dimension we mentioned before. Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few. Like what we say that if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse. So data are sparse. And sometimes in certain place, we will also talking about the resolution.
Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few.

attributes.definition: A characteristic of data where very few data points are present relative to the total number of possible data points.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Describes data where most values are zero or empty, meaning only a small fraction of the possible information is actually present. Think of a huge customer database where each customer has only bought a few items.

extractions.extraction_text: Like what we say that if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse.

attributes.summary_of_insight: E-commerce data is often sparse because a customer typically purchases a very small fraction of the available products.

attributes.definition: The level of detail or granularity at which data is observed or analyzed.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Refers to how finely detailed your data is. Like the difference between a low-quality, pixelated image and a high-quality, sharp image; the resolution affects the patterns you can see.

extractions.extraction_text: We want to talk about different type of the data set. We have the data matrix, document data, transaction data.
data matrix. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes.

attributes.definition: A data set where each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes.
attributes.simplified_explanation: A table where each row represents an item and each column represents a numerical feature of that item.

extractions.extraction_text: document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector.

attributes.definition: Representing documents as vectors by selecting important keywords and counting their occurrences.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Turning text documents into numerical lists (vectors) by counting how often specific keywords appear in each document.

extractions.extraction_text: vector. Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data.

attributes.definition: In computer science, vectors are a fundamental way to represent data for operations, often converting data into numerical (ratio) form.
attributes.simplified_explanation: Vectors are lists of numbers that computers can easily work with to perform calculations and analysis.

extractions.extraction_text: But that is way we try to work in that before 2013. After 2013, how we try to do that? We will talking about that in the text mining part. So maybe three weeks later.

attributes.summary_of_insight: The methods for processing document data have evolved, with newer techniques to be discussed later in text mining.

text:
# LECTURE ANALYSIS: Types of Data Sets
## Video Segment: 110:58 - 114:58

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Sets". It lists two main categories: Structured Data Sets and Unstructured Data Sets. Structured data is described as a collection of data organized in certain formats, often in rows and columns, with a clear, predictable structure. Unstructured data is described as more complex and varied, usually derived from human-generated content like text, images, and videos.

[TRANSCRIPT - 110:58]
So the next one we want to talking about the data set. We have different type of data set. You might heard about the term called structured data or unstructured data. Structured data is you know exactly the meaning about the row and column. Unstructured data is they will change. Sometimes you don't really know how to interpret them. Currently that the human generate content such as image, text, video, we consider them as unstructured data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:36]
Luckily with this AI thing and right now text, image, video already can be converting into structured format, but you still need to be able to know once we convert, are they meaningful or not.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Characteristics of Data Sets". It lists three characteristics: Dimensionality (Curse of Dimensionality), Sparsity (Only presence counts), and Resolution (Patterns depend on the scale). A speech bubble says "Later" next to Sparsity.

[TRANSCRIPT - 111:53]
So we have different kind of characteristic about our data dimension we mentioned before. Sparsity comes from a key word called sparse. Sparse means very few. Like what we say that if you have the record in e-commerce store, like in Amazon. Your data is sparse in that data record. Because they have millions of the record, but then you probably only buy 10 books before. So make your data in the millions then become very sparse. So data are sparse. And sometimes in certain place, we will also talking about the resolution. And that part about sparsity, how to solving them, how to do the resolution, we will talking about later in some of the courses, some of them will be in classification, some of them will be in the text mining.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Types of Data Sets". It lists three types: Data Matrix, Document Data, and Transaction Data.

[TRANSCRIPT - 112:58]
We want to talk about different type of the data set. We have the data matrix, document data, transaction data. So data matrix look like this way. If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes. Okay, they can become data metric. And then we allow them to do the ratio operation. All the value inside need to become the ratio data. So then right here, they need to be ratio data.

[SLIDE DESCRIPTION]
The slide is titled "Data Matrix". It states: "If each object has the same fixed set of numeric attributes". A table shows "Book 1" to "Book 5" with columns for "Price", "Sells", "# Reviews", and "# Readers". The values are numeric.

[TRANSCRIPT - 114:48]
Okay. And the document data is a part that we were talking about later because before 2013, this is before 2013. Okay. And the people actually utilize document data in a vector form. Right here. So they select important keyword in the document. And then after that, for every document, you utilize those important keyword, we got some number, occurrence of the number for that keyword right there. We generate a something called term vector. So each one of them are vector. Why vector? Because in computer science, vector is the way for us to operate. We convert them to vector, so in other word, every number right here are become ratio data. But that is way we try to work in that before 2013. After 2013, how we try to do that? We will talking about that in the text mining part. So maybe three weeks later.
